title: 109_hr3060
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" and includes penalties for terrorist offenses resulting in death. The "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" adds a new offense to Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, stating that anyone who causes death during a terrorist offense will face the death penalty or life imprisonment. The term 'terrorist offense' includes specific federal felony offenses or attempts/conspiracies to commit such offenses. The "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" adds a new offense to Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, stating that anyone who causes death during a terrorist offense will face the death penalty or life imprisonment. The table of sections at the beginning of chapter 113B is amended to include the new offense. The "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" introduces a new offense in Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, for terrorist offenses resulting in death. This includes the denial of federal benefits to terrorists. The "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" adds a new section to Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, stating that individuals or corporations convicted of a terrorist offense may be ineligible for Federal benefits as determined by the court. The "Terrorist Death Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends the table of sections in Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code to include a new item related to benefits and assistance for individuals or corporations convicted of a terrorist offense. SEC. 103. Death penalty procedures for certain air piracy cases occurring before enactment of the Federal Death Penalty Act of 1994. Section 60003 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to allow for the death penalty for individuals convicted of certain aircraft piracy violations committed before the enactment of the Act. The amendment to Section 60003 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 allows for the death penalty for individuals convicted of specific aircraft piracy offenses. The amendment clarifies the criteria for determining if a crime is "especially heinous, cruel, or depraved" by specifying that it involves torture or serious physical abuse to the victim. SEC. 104 of the bill adds terrorism to the list of offenses eligible for the death penalty under certain circumstances. It also modifies aggravating factors for terrorism offenses. Additionally, TITLE II of the bill addresses the prevention of terrorist access to destructive weapons and includes provisions for the death penalty for certain terror-related crimes. SEC. 201 of the bill expands the death penalty to certain terror-related crimes involving nuclear threats, missile systems, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the variola virus. TITLE III--FEDERAL DEATH PENALTY PROCEDURES

SEC. 301. MODIFICATION OF DEATH PENALTY PROVISIONS. Modification of Federal Death Penalty Procedures:
- Elimination of certain procedures under the Controlled Substances Act.
- Modification of mitigating factors in death penalty cases.
- Modification of aggravating factors for offenses resulting in death. The text chunk discusses amendments to federal death penalty procedures, including changes to aggravating factors for offenses resulting in death and the impaneling of new juries in certain circumstances. The amendments to federal death penalty procedures include changes to the impaneling of new juries when a unanimous recommendation cannot be reached and adjustments to the number of peremptory challenges allowed in criminal procedures. Four additional peremptory challenges are allowed when seven, eight, or nine alternates are impaneled.
